byline.original: By MARC SANTORA, SOMINI SENGUPTA and BENJAMIN WEISER

abstract: Federal prosecutors name John W Ashe, former president of United Nations General Assembly, as well as five other people in criminal complaint concerning bribes of more than $1 million from Chinese sources for business deals; case is embarrassing for UN, particularly in light of pledges of greater transparency in wake of previous scandals like oil-for-food program scandal in Iraq; charges stem from investigation of Macau-based developer Ng Lap Seng.
lead_paragraph: John W. Ashe, the former president of the United Nations General Assembly, was named in a criminal complaint outlining a scheme that involved more than $1 million in payments from sources in China.

headline.main: Former U.N. President and Chinese Billionaire Are Accused in Graft Scheme
headline.print_headline: Former U.N. President and Chinese Billionaire Are Accused in Graft Scheme

snippet: John W. Ashe, the former president of the United Nations General Assembly, was named in a criminal complaint outlining a scheme that involved more than $1 million in payments from sources in China.
